text.p: These are the leading stories in the Serbian and Montenegrin press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- SERBIA -
POLITIKA
- Yugoslavia has not held any prisoners of war in its territory since January 1994, says federal foreign ministry in a memorandum for the U.N. Human Rights Commission session in Geneva.
- Committee for protection of rights and interests of displaced persons asks OSCE to supervise local elections in eastern Slavonia and to allow Croatian Serbs living in Yugoslavia to vote.

- Sartid steel works from Smederevo produced 750,000 tonnes of steel last year and plans to produce one million tonnes this year. Last year's exports were worth $85 million, $20 million in January and $15 million in February.
- One of the largest Yugoslav commercial banks Vojvodjanska Banka has charged Deloitte and Touche to make a study for its reorganisation.
- Yugoslav and republican agriculture ministers Nedeljko Sipovac and Jovan Babovic agree that drafting of long-term agriculture development strategy to year 2020 should start.
- Yugoslav airlines JAT is celebrating its 70th anniversary.
NASA BORBA
- Belgrade students set up student parliament.
- Now is the moment to resolve the Kosovo issue with independent Kosovo as a platform of departure, says Hidaet Hiseini, Vice-President of the Democratic League of Kosovo.
- London Euromoney rates Yugoslavia 166th out of 179 countries based on general economic risk.
- The second draft of the information law will be presented this week, says Serbian Information Minister Radmila Milentijevic.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI
- The Yugoslav government plans to sell four of its six 20-year old Lear-jet 25 planes at the price of 500,000 to 800,000 dollars per plane.

- Nothing spectacular expected to happen at the Serbian-Kosovo Albanian round table scheduled in New York from April 7-9 but it is important that we will sit down and talk together, says New Democracy President Dusan MIhajlovic.
BORBA
- Serbia concession law to be passed urgently at next republican parliament session, says Serbian construction minister Branislav Ivkovic.
BLIC
- Bus producer Ikarbus of Zemun plans to incerase production by 30 percent this year. Between 200 and 300 buses were produced last year.
- MONTENEGRO -
POBJEDA
- Inflation in the first three months this year was 6.5 percent in Montenegro and 2.6 percent in Serbia, according to the Federal statistics office.
- Montenegro will reform its secondary school education.

- Montenegro will have a shortage of electric energy worth $20 million this year that the Montenegrin power company will not be able pay for with the present electricity prices, says the company director Slobodan Dakovic.
- There are 65,000 persons registered with the Montenegrin Unemployment Office.

- Internal party struggle in the National Party coincides with friction in the ruling Democratic Party of Socialists ahead of the presidential elections later this year and possible early parliamentary elections.
- Podgorica local bus company will be privatised. -- Belgrade Newsroom +381 11 2224254
